sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• number of mg to administer based on body surface area (BSA); use body weight on day 1 of each cycle for institutional standard BSA calculation; evidence of BSA dosing in obese patients is limited
  • each pixantrone dimaleate vial contains pixantrone base 29 mg; use pixantrone base to calculate the required dose
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, Relapsed or refractory, aggressive, B-cell: 50 mg/m(2) pixantrone base by slow IV infusion over at least 60 minutes on days 1, 8, and 15 of each 28-day cycle for up to 6 cycles (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients younger than 18 years

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• hematologic: day 1 any cycle, delay therapy if absolute neutrophil count less than 1 X 10(9)/L or if platelet count less than 75 X 10(9)/L; may resume once levels meet or exceed 1 X 10(9)/L and 75 X 10(9)/L, respectively
  • hematologic: day 8 or 15 any cycle, grade 1 to 2: platelets 50 X 10(9)/L to lower limit normal (LLN) and absolute neutrophil count (ANC) 1 X 10(9)/L to LLN, no dose or schedule adjustment; grade 3: platelet 25 to less than 50 X 10(9)/L and ANC 0.5 to less than 1 X 10(9)/L, delay therapy until platelet count 50 X 10(9)/L or greater and ANC 1 X 10(9)/L or greater; grade 4: platelets less than 25 X 10(9)/L and ANC less than 0.5 X 10(9)/L, delay therapy until platelet count 50 X 10(9)/L or greater and ANC 1 X 10(9)/L or greater and reduce dose by 20%
  • nonhematologic: grade 3 or 4 drug-related NON-cardiac toxicity other than nausea and vomiting, delay therapy until recovery to grade 1 and reduce dose by 20%
  • nonhematologic: grade 3 or 4 NYHA cardiovascular toxicity or persistent left ventricular ejection fraction decline, delay therapy and monitor until recovery; consider discontinuation for persistent LVEF decline of 15% or greater from baseline
  • hepatic impairment: severe excretory, use not recommended
  • geriatric: 65 years or older, no dose adjustment required
  • obesity: use actual body weight for dose calculation in overweight, obese, or morbidly obese with BMI greater than 25; any standard formula for body surface area calculation acceptable (eg, Mosteller, Dubois and Dubois, Haycock, Gehan and George, or Boyd)

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, Relapsed or refractory, aggressive, B-cell

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• profound bone marrow suppression
  • severe hepatic dysfunction
  • hypersensitivity to pixantrone dimaleate or any components of the product
  • immunization with live virus vaccines

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- cardiotoxicity, including decreased left ventricular ejection fraction or fatal congestive heart failure, may occur during or after treatment; monitoring recommended and temporary or permanent discontinuation may be necessary
  • -- active or dormant cardiovascular disease or risk factors (eg, baseline left ventricular ejection fraction less than 45%, NYHA grade 3 or 4, myocardial infarction within 6 months, doxorubicin or equivalent prior cumulative doses exceeding 450 mg/m(2), severe arrhythmia, uncontrolled hypertension or angina) increases risk of cardiac toxicity; evaluate risk to benefit prior to therapy initiation and monitoring recommended
  • -- prior or concurrent radiotherapy to the mediastinal area increases risk of cardiac toxicity; monitoring recommended
  • Hepatic:
  • hepatic impairment, mild or moderate
  • Hematologic:
  • -- secondary hematological malignancies (eg, acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplastic syndrome) during or after therapy have been reported
  • -- severe myelosuppression, including neutropenia (predominantly), leukopenia, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and lymphopenia, may occur; monitoring recommended and dose adjustment may be necessary
  • Immunologic:
  • -- severe infections (eg, pneumonia, cellulitis, bronchitis, sepsis) including hospitalization, septic shock, and death, have been reported; use not recommended in patients with active, severe, or history of recurrent or chronic infections, or underlying conditions predisposing to serious infections
  • Renal:
  • -- renal impairment
  • Reproductive:
  • -- use not recommended during pregnancy or in women not using contraception; men and women must use effective contraception during and up to 6 months after treatment
  • Other:
  • -- extravasation may occur; discontinue immediately and restart using another vein
  • -- photosensitivity may occur; protective clothing and sunscreen recommended
  • -- sodium-restricted diet; product contains approximately 1000 mg (43 mmol) sodium per dose after dilution
  • -- tumor lysis syndrome may occur; monitoring recommended in patients at high risk (elevated LDH, high tumor volume, high baseline uric acid or serum phosphate)
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- immunizations may be ineffective if given during therapy
  • -- previous anthracycline or anthracenedione exposure increases risk of cardiac toxicity; monitoring recommended
  • -- use with other cardiotoxic agents increases risk of cardiac toxicity; monitoring recommended

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Alopecia (10% or greater), Discoloration of skin (10% or greater)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (10% or greater), Vomiting (10% or greater)
  • Hematologic:Anemia (10% or greater), Leukopenia (10% or greater), Lymphocytopenia (10% or greater), Neutropenia (10% or greater), Thrombocytopenia (10% or greater)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (10% or greater)
  • Renal:Urine color abnormal (10% or greater)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Bundle branch block (1% to less than 10%), Cardiac dysrhythmia (0.1% to less than 1%), Congestive heart failure (1% to less than 10%), Decreased cardiac function (1% to less than 10%), Heart failure
  • Gastrointestinal:Rectal hemorrhage (0.1% to less than 1%), Salmonella gastroenteritis (0.1% to less than 1%)
  • Hematologic:Febrile neutropenia (1% to less than 10%), Hematologic neoplasm (0.1% to less than 1%), Neutropenia, Grade 3 to 4, Pancytopenia (0.1% to less than 1%)
  • Neurologic:Meningitis (0.1% to less than 1%), Oral paresthesia (0.1% to less than 1%)
  • Renal:Oliguria (0.1% to less than 1%)
  • Respiratory:Pleural effusion (0.1% to less than 1%), Pneumonitis (0.1% to less than 1%)
  • Other:Cellulitis (0.1% to less than 1%), Shock (0.1% to less than 1%)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • avoid contact with eyes
  • each pixantrone dimaleate vial contains pixantrone base 29 mg; use pixantrone base to calculate the required dose
  • reconstitute with 5 mL NS (resulting concentration, 5.8 mg/mL) and further dilute by injecting the required dose into 250-mL NS infusion bag; final concentration of pixantrone base in infusion bag should be less than 580 mcg/mL; use immediately; store no longer than 24 hours at room temperature (15 to 25 degrees C) after reconstituted
  • lyophilized, dark blue powder for solution for infusion; solution remains dark blue after reconstitution and dilution
  • IV use only; single-use vials; infuse slowly over at least 60 minutes with a polyethersulfone, acrylic, or cellulose acetate 0.2 micrometer pore in-line filter
